channel.title: physics on fluids
channel.description: Recent content in physics on fluids

item.title: archimedes law
item.description: when a solid is immersed (fully or partially) in a fluid, and there’s a uniform gravitational field Ëâ†—g = -gâ†—eâ‚zâ‚Ë, the total upwards force of the fluid on the body (“buoyant force”) equals the weight of displaced fluid.

item.title: archimedes law
item.description: Â¶ archimedes' law: when a solid is immersed (fully or partially) in a fluid, and there’s a uniform gravitational field Ëâ†—g = -gâ†—eâ‚zâ‚Ë, the total upwards force of the fluid on the body (“buoyant force”) equals the weight of displaced fluid.

item.title: barenblatt equation
item.description: BARENBLATT’S EQUATION Â¶ recall, the modified porous medium equation ğ{t}{u(r,t)} = DÂ·Î”â‚dâ‚Â·u(r,t)â½1+nâ¾ the case Ën = 0Ë is the barenblatt equation. this is a fluid that can expand and contract irreversibly in response to a fluid flow through it. ?? what does it mean, to expand and contract irreversibly? DIMENSIONAL ANALYSIS OF BARENBLATT’S EQUATION Â¶ barenblatt’s equation in 1d: ğ{t}{u(x,t)} = DÎºÂ·ğn{2}{x}{u(x,t)} where D == Ã·12 ğ{t}{u} > 0 == Ã·{1+Îµ}{2} ğ{t}{u} < 0 ËÎºË and ËÎµË are constants.

item.title: barotropic fluid
barotropic model of dark energy
item.description: Barotropic fluid: a fluid where density is a function of pressure only (although a “perfect fluid” has a suspiciously similar definition…) The key thing is, the relation between pressure and density is given by Ëw = P/ÏË, where ËwË is an equation of state parameter. Define w' = Ã·{dw}{dÍºln(a)} Insert Ëw = Pâ‚Xâ‚/Ïâ‚Xâ‚Ë and use the product rule: w' &= Ã·{d}{dÍºln(a)} (Pâ‚Xâ‚â‹„Ã·1{Ïâ‚Xâ‚}) &= Ã·{dÍºPâ‚Xâ‚}{dÍºln(a)} Ã·1{Ïâ‚Xâ‚} + Pâ‚Xâ‚ Ã·{dÍºÏâ‚Xâ‚â½-1â¾}{dÍºln(a)} &= Ã·{dÍºPâ‚Xâ‚}{dÍºÏâ‚Xâ‚} Ã·{dÍºÏâ‚Xâ‚}{dÍºln(a)} Ã·1{Ïâ‚Xâ‚} - w Ïâ‚Xâ‚ Ã·1{Ïâ‚Xâ‚â½2â¾} Ã·{dÍºÏâ‚Xâ‚}{dÍºln(a)} (in the last step: use the chain rule to expand Ëdâ‚ln(a)â‚Pâ‚Xâ‚Ë, and likewise for Ëdâ‚ln(a)â‚Ïâ‚Xâ‚â½-1â¾Ë, and substitute ËPâ‚Xâ‚ = wÏâ‚Xâ‚Ë)

item.title: bernoulli's theorem
item.description: what is the entropy of a fluid? what does it mean? « Â¶ bernoulli’s principle: comes from conservation of energy. in a steady flow, the sum of all forms of energy is the same at all points (free of viscous forces). KE + PE + internal energy = constant. means that an increase in speed of fluid occurs simultaneously with decrease in static pressure.

item.title: boundary
item.description: in nature you find fluids that rotate nearly rigidly. this means fluids with a uniform distribution of vorticity. how can you have fluids that rotate regularly, and yet maintain a uniform velocity distribution? it’s best to analyse these “rotating” fluids in a rotating reference frame, where the unperturbed fluid is at rest, and ALL perturbations are influenced by coriolis force(s) [WHYtf is this plural]. this results in “surprising” phenomena.

item.title: boundary layers
item.description: when a fluid meets a solid surface, e.g. the edge of an airplane wing or a spoon stirring tea. ilya intermolecular forces that decelerate the fluid rapidly in a thin boundary layer along the surface. this deceleration gives rise to circulation and vorticity into the flow. the vorticity diffuses into the bulk flow, thickening the boundary layer. I don’t understand p745. if the fluid is nonbarotropic due to spatially variable chemical composition or spatiallly variable T, then pressure gradients can also create vorticity, as described by the first term on the RHS of the vorticity evolution law, Ë-Î´ivp Ã— Â¥divÏ/Ïâ½2â¾Ë.

item.title: bucket
item.description: how long does it take for a bucket with a small hole in the side to empty? you can start with the continuity equation: Aâ‚1â‚ vâ‚1â‚ = Aâ‚2â‚ vâ‚2â‚ the flux out: Aâ‚2â‚ âˆš{2gh} convert to volumetric flux: V = Aâ‚2â‚vâ‚2â‚t so time taken is: t = V / Aâ‚2â‚âˆš{2gh} [attach table of results] not entirely sure this is correct. experimentally, I find it empties slower.

item.title: christoffel symbol
item.description: for a n-dimensional space, the christoffel symbol is a nÃ—nÃ—n array of numbers that describes the curvature of a surface. you calculate the christoffel symbol (that is, the components of the christoffel symbol) from the metric tensor of the surface/manifold. (the metric tensor is what defines the distance between points on the manifold). the christoffel symbol defines the covariant derivative. this is a special derivative for a curved surface that accounts for the curvature of the surface.

item.title: conservation laws
item.description: conservation of mass, eulerian Â¶ in the eulerian approach to mass conservation, you monitor the change in density at a given point in space, rather than moving with the flow [thorne p692]. Â¶ when dealing with continua, all conservation of mass laws tend to have the form Ëğâ‚tâ‚Ë(density of something) = Ëâˆ‡â¦Ë(flux of that thing). ie, rate of change of density wrt time = rate of change of flux wrt space

item.title: constructing the mechanical stress tensor
item.description: Â¶ consider a small area element, dâ†—A. momentum flows through this area in the +ve direction. the MASS FLOW RATE thru the surface is Ïâ†—v â¦ dâ†—A = dot(momentumÍºdensity, vectorÍºareaÍºelement) multiply by velocity to get the MOMENTUM FLOW RATE: á¸â‚tâ‚â¬€p = (Ïâ¬€v)Â·(â¬€vâ¦dâ¬€A) this is just the force Ëâ¬€F = á¸â¬€pË across the area element Ëdâ†—AË. from the definition of the stress tensor, you can compute the force by inserting Ëdâ†—AË into the 2nd arg of a stress tensor,

item.description: Â¶ consider a small area element, dâ†—A. momentum flows through this area in the +ve direction. the MASS FLOW RATE thru the surface is Ïâ†—v â¦ dâ†—A = dot(momentumÍºdensity, vectorÍºareaÍºelement) multiply by velocity to get the MOMENTUM FLOW RATE: á¸â‚tâ‚â¬€p = (Ïâ¬€v)Â·(â¬€vâ¦dâ¬€A) this is just the force Ëâ¬€F = á¸â¬€pË across the area element Ëdâ†—AË. from the definition of the stress tensor, you can compute the force by inserting Ëdâ†—AË into the 2nd arg of a stress tensor,

item.title: density
item.description: the density Î© is the ratio of the actual observed density Ï to the critical density Ïâ‚câ‚ of a friedmann universe. the ratio determines the overall geometry of the universe. when they’re equal, flat. in earlier models that didn’t have a cosmological constant, critical density was defined as the watershed point between an expanding and contracting universe. Ïâ‚câ‚ is estimated to be 5 atoms of monatomic hydrogen per cubic metre today.

item.title: deriving the vorticity equation from navier-stokes in 2d
item.description: Start with the incompressible Navier-Stokes equation ğâ‚tâ‚â†—v + (â†—vâ¦âˆ‡)â†—v = Î½âˆ‡â½2â¾â†—v - Ã·1ÏÂ·âˆ‡p ğ“®ğ“º{611} where Ëâ†—v = â†—v(â†—r,t)Ë is the flow velocity (vector field) Ëp = p(â†—r,t)Ë is the pressure (scalar field) ËÏË is the density ËÎ½Ë is the kinematic viscosity, ËÎ½ = Î¼/ÏË Some context: the NSE is an equation for the time evolution of the fluid’s velocity field. The specific form of the equation derives from momentum conservation (and whatever assumptions you deign to make about the fluid, e.

item.title: diffusion, similarity solutions, intermediate asymptotics
item.description: RECAP: ANOMALOUS DIMENSIONS Â¶ when anomalous dimensions arise, it means there’s a microscopic length at work. this microscopic length scale affects the thermo functions and the correlation function asymptotically near the critical point mmly this means you can’t approximate a function Ëf(x)Ë with Ëf(x = 0)Ë when Ëx â†’ 0Ë. that kind of limit approximation is not valid. Â¶ so basically, whenever there’s a function Ëf(x)Ë that you can’t replace with Ëf(0)Ë when ËxË is small, it means there’s an anomalous dimension.

item.title: equation of hydrostatics
item.description: -âˆ‡p - Ïâˆ‡Ï† = 0

item.title: equation of state
item.description: an equation that relates Ï to p. in a perfect fluid, the EOS is Ï = const. in a barotropic fluid, Ï is a function of p.

item.title: euler equation
item.description: Â¶ take the momentum conservation law for a fluid, ğâ‚tâ‚(Ïâ†—v) + âˆ‡â¦T = Ïâ†—g differentiate then invoke the mass conservation law, ğâ‚tâ‚Ï + âˆ‡â¦(Ïâ†—v) = 0 you get the euler equation: ÆŠâ‚tâ‚â†—v = ğâ‚tâ‚â†—v + (â†—vâ¦âˆ‡)â†—v = -Ã·1ÏÂ·âˆ‡p + â†—g Â¶ the LHS is the advective derivative of â†—v, ie the acceleration of the fluid. from the RHS, you can see there are two terms that cause the acceleration: gravity, and the pressure gradient.

item.title: Flow past a Cylinder
item.description: Consider a cylinder placed perpendicular to a flow. Assume Ëâ¬€vË is small compared to the speed of sound, so you can ignore compressibility. Assume gravity is negligible. Parameters: ËdË, the diameter of the flow (and âˆ´ characteristic length scale of the problem) ËVË, the velocity of the flow far before it reaches the cylinder (“upstream velocity”). ËÏË, density ËÎ½Ë, kinematic viscosity Reynolds number: Re = Ã·1Î½ Vd Note: if you had a flow where the sound speed Ëcâ‚sâ‚Ë is sufficiently high to to invalidateincompressibility, then you can define the mach number (another dimensionless number)

item.title: flow speed
item.description: the magnitude of the flow velocity

item.title: hydrodynamic continuity equation
item.description: is essentially a statement of mass conservation: ğâ‚tâ‚Ï = -âˆ‡â¦(Ïâ¬€v)

item.title: hydrodynamics
item.description: HYDRODYNAMICS Â¶ hydrodynamics is when the fluid velocity Ëâ†—v(â†—x,t)Ë is nonzero (as opposed to hydrostatics). CONSERVATION conservation of mass, eulerian Â¶ in the eulerian approach to mass conservation, you monitor the change in density at a given point in space, rather than moving with the flow [thorne p692]. Â¶ when dealing with continua, all conservation of mass laws tend to have the form Ëğâ‚tâ‚Ë(density of something) = Ëâˆ‡â¦Ë(flux of that thing).

item.title: hydrodynamics
item.description: study of fluids in motion. assume the flow velocity Ëâ¬€v(â¬€x,t)Ë is nonzero.

item.title: hydrostatics
item.description: STRESS, Ïƒ Â¶ is a quantity that describes the forces in an object that cause deformation (strain). describes the internal forces that neighbouring particles exert on each other, in a continuous material. Â¶ defined as force per unit area. Â¶ compressive stress: is when forces (like tension or compression) cause an object to become compressed. the bigger these forces and the smaller the cross sectional area, the greater the stress.

item.title: hydrostatics
item.description: theory of fluids at rest

item.title: ideal fluid
item.description: Â¶ you can decompose the stress tensor into: an isotropic pressure term a viscous term linear in the rate of shear (velocity gradient) if the viscous stress is negligible (in many cases it is) and diffusive heatconductivity is negligible, the fluid is ideal.

item.title: incompressible flows
item.description: Â¶ define [INCOMPRESSIBLE FLOW] : a flow where the density is constant in a parcel of fluid. incompressible flows obey: âˆ‡â¦â†—v = 0 Ëâ†—vË is the flow velocity (a vector field since it’s a flow). note this equation has the same form as the equation for a solenoidal field. indeed, for incompressible flows the velocity field is solenoidal. Â¶ when can you assume the fluid density is constant? well, if the flow velocity is much smaller than the speed of sound (“highly subsonic flow”) && gravity isn’t strong enough to compress the fluid significantly, then changes in fluid density are negligible.

item.title: incompressible fluid
item.description: Â¶ if you assume density is constant, you’re saying the fluid is incompressible (pq to compress the fluid, you have to induce some kind of density variation) Â¶ incompressible fluid: you’re assuming variations of pressure are so small that changes in density are negligible Â¶ to be clear, this is an approximation. approximating constant ËÏË is only valid when: the velocities of the flow are much less than the speed of sound in the fluid, then you don’t have to worry about density variations Â¶ incompressible fluids obey

item.title: ionisation energy
item.description: the energy needed to remove the most loosely bound outer electron in a neutral atom.

item.title: mach number
item.description: mach number M = Ã·V{câ‚sâ‚} where Ëcâ‚sâ‚Ë is the sound speed. the mach number is dimensionless. this is a useful quantity in flows where Ëcâ‚sâ‚Ë is high enough that the incompressibility approximation is invalid.

item.title: misc notes from tong
item.description: if you take any system in the big ol' universe, and add heat, you’ll find that the dynamics of that system will be governed by (i.e. can be described by) the equations of fluid mechanics. “when things get hot, everything looks the same.” the eqs of fluid mech also describe the event horizon of a black hole (obviously) at the microscopic level fluids are flipping complicated. what we’re mostly interested in is: the PATTERNS that emerge in the COLLECTIVE behaviour of the large system of molecules/atoms/things.

item.title: modified porous medium equation
item.description: INTRO Â¶ you can’t always get similarity solutions using dimensional analysis, because ADs can occur. Â¶ goal: show an example of this (how you can’t always get SSs using DA) by looking at the LT bhvr of a slight modification to the diffusion equation will show that a naive application of DA fails to get the correct LT bhvr, BUT a modded similarity solution with an AD does get the correct LT bhvr Â¶ order:

item.title: navier stokes
item.description: Â¶ the navier stokes equations âˆ‡â¦â†—v = 0 ÏÂ·ğ{t}{â†—v} = -âˆ‡p + Î¼âˆ‡â½2â¾â†—v + ÏF Â¶ the conservation of mass equation âˆ‡â¦â†—v = 0 aka the incompressibility equation expanded: (ğ{x}{}â†‘x + ğ{y}{}â†‘y + ğ{z}{}â†‘z)â¦(vâ‚xâ‚â†‘x + vâ‚yâ‚â†‘y + vâ‚zâ‚â†‘z) = 0 ğ{x}{vâ‚xâ‚} + ğ{y}{vâ‚yâ‚} + ğ{z}{vâ‚zâ‚} = 0 all this equation says is, mass is conserved Â¶ newton’s 2nd law, mass Ã— acceleration = force

item.title: perfect fluid
item.description: Â¶ a fluid that you can describe using only the density Ï and pressure p. Â¶ or: a fluid that doesn’t have viscosity or shear stresses. Â¶ you can decompose the stress tensor into: an isotropic pressure term a viscous term linear in the rate of shear (velocity gradient) if the viscous stress is negligible (in many cases it is) and heat conductivity is negligible, then the fluid is ideal.

item.title: power spectrum of a cube
item.description: A cosmological cube: The contrast in the image shows (somewhat) the local variations in the (over)density field. The power spectrum is essentially a measure of the density contrast in space. Some theory: the fractional overdensity ËÎ´(â¬€x)Ë describes the deviation of the density field, ËÏ(â¬€x)Ë, from the average density, ËâŸ¨ÏâŸ©Ë Î´(â¬€x) = Ã·{ Ï(â¬€x) - âŸ¨ÏâŸ© }{ âŸ¨ÏâŸ© } where ËÏ(â¬€x)Ë is the density at point Ëâ¬€xË and ËâŸ¨ÏâŸ©Ë is the average density over (all) space.

item.title: pressure
item.description: the normal force per unit area.

item.title: pressure on an infinitesimal cube of liquid
reynolds number
item.description: Â¶ is basically a metric for quantifying/comparing viscosities. you compare the [viscosity] ËÎ½Ë with the product of the flow’s characteristic velocity ËVË and its characteristic length scale ËLË. Re = Ã·{LV}{Î½} this is the reynolds number it’s dimensionless flows with ËRe < 1Ë are dominated by viscosity flows with ËRe > 1Ë can be influenced by viscosity, especially when it acts near boundaries, BUT the viscous stresses are negligible over most of the flow’s volume

item.title: reynolds number
item.description: Â¶ kinematic viscosity ËÎ½Ë has dimensions Ëlengthâ½2â¾/timeË. to quantiy viscosity in fluid flow, you compare ËÎ½Ë with the product of the flow’s characteristic velocity ËVË and its characteristic length scale ËLË. Re = Ã·{LV}{Î½} this is the reynolds number it’s dimensionless flows with ËRe < 1Ë are dominated by viscosity flows with ËRe > 1Ë can be influenced by viscosity, especially when it acts near boundaries, BUT the viscous stresses are negligible over most of the flow’s volume

item.title: shear stress
item.description: SHEAR FORCES forces that acts on one part of a body in a certain direction, and another part in the opposite direction Â¶ if the forces are aligned (collinear), then they are just tension or compression forces SHEAR STRESS Ï„ the component of stress that’s coplanar with the body’s cross section Ï„ = Ã·FA ËAË is the cross sectional area of the material that’s parallel to the applied force points are coplanar if there’s a plane that contains them all Â¶ “ordinary” stress comes from the force vector component perpendicular to the material cross section.

item.title: shear stress
item.description: Â¶ shear stress: the component of stress that’s coplanar from the material’s cross section. denoted ËÏ„Ë: Ï„ = F/A ËFË is the force applied, ËAË is the crosssectional area of the material whose area is parallel to the applied force vector Â¶ “ordinary” stress comes from the force vector component perpendicular to the material cross section.

item.title: strain
item.description: Â¶ strain is a measure of deformation of an object. it describes the displacement between particles relative to a reference length Â¶ functional form of deformation: â†—x = F(â†—x') â†—x' is an array of reference positions for points of the body deformations have units of length Â¶ strains are usually dimensionless Â¶ whenever a solid material undergoas a strain (deformation), there is an internal elastic stress that causes the object to restore to its original non-deformed state (like the spring force)

item.title: stress
item.description: Â¶ is a quantity that describes the forces in an object that cause deformation (strain). describes the internal forces that neighbouring particles exert on each other, in a continuous material. Â¶ defined as force per unit area. Â¶ compressive stress: is when forces (like tension or compression) cause an object to become compressed. the bigger these forces and the smaller the cross sectional area, the greater the stress. is why stress is defined as force per unit area Â¶ dimensions: Ë[Ïƒ] = Lâ½-1â¾ M Tâ½-2â¾Ë

item.title: stress tensor
item.description: GOAL: describe the internal forces in a material/body in terms of a tensor. STRESSES & INTERNAL FORCES Â¶ the STRESSES in a material are the various internal forces that maintain its form. suppose you dissect a 3d object with a plane. take a small area element of the plane. the material on the left of the area element will exert a force Î”F to the right, and v.v. Â¶ PRESSURE in a static liquid is one kind of stress.

item.title: stress tensor
item.description: GOAL: describe the internal forces in a material/body in terms of a tensor. STRESSES & INTERNAL FORCES Â¶ the STRESSES in a material are the various internal forces that maintain its form. suppose you dissect a 3d object with a plane. take a small area element of the plane. the material on the left of the area element will exert a force Î”F to the right, and v.v. Â¶ PRESSURE in a static liquid is one kind of stress.

item.title: the vorticity equation in a rotating frame
item.description: The NSE: ÆŠâ‚tâ‚â†—v = Î½âˆ‡â½2â¾â†—v - Ã·1Ïâˆ‡p ğ“®ğ“º{621} where ËÆŠâ‚tâ‚Ë is the advective derivative, ËÆŠâ‚tâ‚ = ğâ‚tâ‚ + (â†—vâ¦âˆ‡)Ë. Suppose we’re now in a rotating reference frame RF that’s rotating at angular velocity Ëâ†—Î©Ë w.r.t. the inertial frame IF. Since all the vector quantities are now fixed in the rotating frame, you have to transform them to a form that’s valid in the inertial frame. Let Ëâ†—rË be the position vector, Ëâ†—r = âˆ‘â‚iâ‚râ‚iâ‚â†‘eâ‚iâ‚Ë.

item.title: thin liquid
item.description: a liquid where you ignore viscosity. von neumann called it “dry water” since this approximation is a fairly large departure from the way real liquids behave.

item.title: turbulence
item.description: RECAP: LAMINAR PIPE FLOW Â¶ the flow velocity profile is parabolic (across the cylindrical cross section). you can achieve this form by balancing the stress across the surface. Â¶ the rate of flow is proportional to the 4th power of pipe diameter: flowÍºrateÍº(volumetricÍºflux) âˆ dâ½4â¾ Â¶ reynolds number: Reâ‚pipeâ‚ = Ã·1Î½ âŸ¨vâŸ©d Â¶ experimentally pipe flow is only laminar up to a critical Re number, Ëâˆ¼10â½3â¾-10â½5â¾Ë. the exact value depends on smoothness of the walls and the pipe entrance.

item.title: velocity profile
item.description: the flow velocity evaluated along a line.

item.title: viscosity
item.description: Â¶ physically: viscosity is a measure of how easily a fluid yields to a shear stress. any time you apply a shear to a fluid, the fluid will move. fluids that more more easily are less viscous, and v.v. Â¶ think about the fluid as a series of parallel plates. if there is a shear force, the plates move at different rates. Â¶ pick two plates, let d be the distance between them, and let Ëvâ‚0â‚Ë be the speed of the slower one.

item.title: viscous flows
item.description: FLUID MOTION RECAP Â¶ the laws of motion for a fluid are contained in the equation ğ{t}{â†—v} + (â†—vâ¦âˆ‡)â†—v = -Ã·1ÏÂ·âˆ‡p - âˆ‡Ï† + Ã·1ÏÂ·â†—fâ‚viscâ‚ Â¶ in the dry water approximation you leave out the last term, ie neglect viscous effects Â¶ another (additional) approximation is assuming the fluid is incompressible, so âˆ‡â¦â†—v = 0 Â¶ the incompressible approximation is good when flow speeds are much slower than the speed of sound.

item.title: vorticity
item.description: the curl of the velocity field â¬€Î© = âˆ‡Ã—â¬€v

item.title: vorticity
item.description: VORTICITY Â¶ define vorticity, Ëâ†—Î©Ë, the curl of the velocity field Ëâ†—vË â†—Î© = âˆ‡Ã—â†—v this is also a vector field Â¶ what vorticity actually is: take a small fluid element. consider how this fluid element moves over a short period of time ËdtË each “bit” of fluid in the fluid element has a small displacement in this interval. let the displacement of this bit be Ëâ†—Îµ = â†—vdtË the gradient of the displacement Ëâ†—ÎµË will be comprised of an expansion, rotation, and shear.

item.title: what is a fluid
item.description: Â¶ fluids are macroscopic. two reasons: the macroscopic continuum approximation is valid. ie observable quantities of the fluid (flow velocity, density, etc) VARY SMOOTHLY in space and time, at macroscopic scales. this is because the mean free paths of the molecules in a fluid are SMALL compared to macroscopic length scales. uh, how do we actually know this about the mean free path of molecules in a fluid?

item.title: what is a fluid
item.description: Â¶ fluids are macroscopic. two reasons: the macroscopic continuum approximation is valid. ie observable quantities of the fluid (flow velocity, density, etc) VARY SMOOTHLY in space and time, at macroscopic scales. this is because the mean free paths of the molecules in a fluid are SMALL compared to macroscopic length scales. uh, how do we actually know this about the mean free path of molecules in a fluid?
